Award.AbstractNarration:
A 3-manifold looks like the 3-dimensional space locally. The classical physics describes the universe we live in as a 3-manifold. Hyperbolic geometry is a (non-Euclidean) geometric model satisfying Euclid's first four postulates but not the fifth (the parallel postulate). It turns out that hyperbolic geometry is much more important than Euclidean geometry for 3-manifolds. Thurston's and Perelman's works imply that "most" 3-manifolds have a hyperbolic geometric structure (i.e., they are hyperbolic 3-manifolds). These hyperbolic 3-manifolds can be described by so-called discrete groups of two-by-two matrices, and their covering spaces correspond to subgroups of these discrete groups. Although subgroups of the matrix groups may seem easy to understand, various properties of covering spaces of hyperbolic 3-manifolds are actually quite mysterious. The PI plans to investigate covering spaces of hyperbolic 3-manifolds by various geometric and algebraic methods.

The main goal of this project is to investigate finite covers of hyperbolic 3-manifolds, and to use finite covers of fibered hyperbolic 3-manifolds to study finite covers of pseudo-Anosov maps. The research will be based on tools developed during the recent progress on the Virtual Haken and Virtual Fibered Conjectures. In particular, the PI will focus on three topics. The first topic is about the asymptotic behavior of topological invariants of finite covers of 3-manifolds (e.g., the Seifert volume, the size of homological torsion). The second topic is to use finite covers of hyperbolic 3-manifolds to study finite covers of pseudo-Anosov maps (e.g., the virtual homological spectral radii of pseudo-Anosov maps). The third topic is to study the mapping tori of small dilatation pseudo-Anosov maps (e.g., to find the explicit finite collection of hyperbolic 3-manifolds that generates all pseudo-Anosov maps of smallest dilatation). Methods from hyperbolic geometry, low-dimensional topology, geometric group theory, dynamical systems, and metric geometry will be involved in the work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the universe we live in is a 3-dimensional world, it is important for mathematicians to study the global structure of various 3-dimensional spaces, which are called 3-manifolds. Hyperbolic geometry is a non-Euclidean geometric model satisfying Euclid's first four postulates but not the fifth (the parallel postulate). It turns out that hyperbolic geometry is much more important than Euclidean geometry for 3-manifolds, since Thurston's and Perelman's works imply that "most" 3-manifolds are hyperbolic 3-manifolds. During the life of this award, the PI studied the topological, geometric and algebraic aspects of (hyperbolic) 3-manifolds, using tools from 3-manifold topology, hyperbolic geometry and geometric group theory. 


Intellectual Merit:

One project was to study the set of finite covers of hyperbolic 3-manifolds. The basic philosophy is that the set of all finite covers of a single hyperbolic 3-manifold is as complicated as the set of all 3-manifolds. The PI and his collaborators proved that the Seifert volumes of finite covers of 3-manifolds with positive simplicial volume grow faster than the linear rate, which reveals a different behavior from the simplicial volume. The PI and his collaborator promoted the PI’s previous virtual 2-domination theorem to virtual 1-domination, that is, every closed hyperbolic 3-manifold has a finite cover that admits a degree-1 map to any prefixed closed 3-manifold. The PI also gave a relation between the virtual homological spectral radii of pseudo-Anosov maps and the Alexander polynomials of finite covers of their mapping tori.

In the above project, one crucial ingredient is the subgroup separability of hyperbolic 3-manifold groups. Another project in this award was to study the subgroup separability (LERFness) of fundamental groups of 3-manifolds. The PI proved that a 3-manifold with empty tori boundary has LERF fundamental group if and only if it supports one of Thurston’s eight geometries, which gave a surprising relationship between the geometry structure of 3-manifolds and the group theoretic property of 3-manifold group. The PI gave a topological characterization on subgroup separability of a subgroup of a 3-manifold group. The PI and his collaborator also gave a relation between subgroup separability and subgroup distortion of subgroups of 3-manifold group, and the only distortion function can show up in 3-manifold groups are: linear, quadratic, exponential and double exponential.

Besides the above results on 3-manifolds, the PI and his collaborators also generalized the representation volume to manifolds of dimension at least 4, and proved that any representation of the mapping class group that maps the Dehn twist to some special matrix is not faithful.


Broader Impacts: 

The PI is currently supervising a graduate student at Rutgers University, who is working on the mapping class group of infinite type surfaces, and his research leads to advances in mathematical knowledge. The PI has also been involved in other aspects of graduate mentoring at Rutgers, including: running reading courses, graduate courses, serving on oral and thesis committees, organizing informal seminars. At the undergraduate level, the PI has advised several students on their internships in industry, independent study, summer research and senior thesis. In particular, one undergraduate student advised by the PI on his senior thesis is currently a graduate student at the University of Colorado Boulder, and another undergraduate student advised by the PI on her independent study is currently a graduate student at the Georgia Institute of Technology.

The results of this project have been widely disseminated by various ways, including conference talks, colloquiums and seminar talks, as well as a mini-course on the topology of 3-manifolds. The PI also wrote a survey paper with Yi Liu that reviews the proof of Agol’s virtual specialization theorem of 3-manifold groups, as well as the further developments on this topic. The PI has been organizing the topology seminar of University of California Berkeley and Rutgers New Brunswick from 2016 to present.
